newsitem.title: CANADA: TransCanada says Express pipe still behind.
newsitem.headline: TransCanada says Express pipe still behind.

text.p: The new Express crude oil pipeline to the United States from Alberta is still operating well below its capacity and TransCanada PipeLines Ltd does not expect "meaningful" earnings from it until next year, TransCanada officials said on Wednesday.

Longer than expected refurbishment of the Platte pipeline, which ships oil to southern Illinois from the end of the new line in Wyoming, was keeping volumes around the project's break-even rate, said Stephen Letwin, president of TCPL unit TransCanada Energy USA.
In energy processing, the company's acquisition of Enron Corp's Louisiana gas liquids operations in January this year had not produced the targeted eight to 10 percent this year, Hodgins said.
"At this point, we don't think we can reach that level," he said. "If product prices move up, we expect we will be earning a full return on these assets beginning later this year."

TransCanada said last week it modified its 1998 Canadian natural gas mainline expansion plans in a move that would see it construct lower cost low-pressure pipeline facilities resulting in lower tolls for shippers.
The 456 million cubic feet a day expansion, originally estimated to cost C$1.1 billion, is now estimated at C$877.6 million.

An application for a new two billion cubic feet a day line to Emerson, Manitoba from Empress, Alberta -- which would connect with the proposed Viking Voyageur pipeline to serve U.S. Midwest markets -- was expected to be filed with Canada's National Energy Board later this year.
Hodgins said the C$225 million reduction in spending for 1998 facilities would reduce TransCanada's planned equity issue next year by about C$70 million to about C$350 million.
